properties.description: The trees stand metres apart, wide enough for a herd of elephants to meander between the trunks, across the dry, leaf covered floor. The dense canopy shields these wandering beasts from the midday sun. The forest is centuries old, the ebony trees 200 years old, merely teenagers. But there has been a cull, like Logan’s Run for the forest, all the mature trees have been cut down, milled for wood. They can’t grow fast enough to keep up - and now they are endangered.  Things are changing. Americans come in and buy the mills, renovate, say they will pay better wages, make the conditions better, to the watchword “sustainable”... for at least 5% of the wood they source.
properties.title: Ebony Wood

properties.description: Over a decade ago there was outrage against mahogany from the Amazon rainforest. The demand for the precious wood had added to the drastic loss of forest coverage and fragmented the forest, disrupting ecological pathways. About 10 per cent of the Amazon forest had already been lost in 2001. That year, the Brazilian government brought in a certification program for the wood, which capped the amount of mahogany logging allowed. Deforestation rates have indeed fallen, in part due to decreased logging. There is still a good deal of illegal logging, with all the associated violence that is borne of an endeavour working outside the law. The criminals are driven to logging areas set aside to preserve indigenous peoples’ way of life.
properties.title: Mahogany Wood

properties.description: Great chains on great cranes clank and clink as they haul their heavy loads. Great planks, bundled and covered in cloth, heave off trucks and onto ships, swinging above the water and the decks. Shouts and laughs fill the air, while money changes hands and views pass lips, licked clean of sweat in the heat. Where do you come from and where do you go? Most of these people have little interest even in what you are
properties.address: Val de Cães International Airport (BEL) - Belém - Pará, Brazil
properties.placename: Val de Cães International Airport (BEL) - Belém - Pará, Brazil
properties.title: Shipping Port

properties.description: The heat is barely tolerable, the air even less so. But Bob was used to it, and he had on his mask, overalls and thick, thick gloves as he checked the temperature on the continuous casting machine in the foundry. Looking at a worn join on the water cooling system, he pondered how long it had been since the last safety inspection by OSHA. He turned away at a cheery “Howdy Bob!” from Erol the floor manager, just before a small stream of steam began to escape the lower side of the join.
properties.title: Bronze

properties.description: “It’s sustainable,” says the large man with a beard sitting opposite Maggie in the boardroom. A blue coffee jug on the tabletop rattles as she placed her mug down. “Alright, I’ll get the contract drawn up and we can go from there,” says Maggie with a bright but brittle smile. What was she going to do? she asked herself. One supplier was just as good as another, and if you want red cedar wood, the fact of the matter is that trees have to be chopped down for it. Unless of course you used reclaimed wood, interjected a timid voice in her head. If only Jo hadn’t sent through that piece of Greenpeace propaganda. Surely logging wasn’t causing that much ecological damage. // Ask the bears. Their homes are getting smaller. They need 500 square kilometres to find enough food. What happens when they don’t have enough room to roam? (http://bear71.nfb.ca)
properties.title: Red Cedar Wood

properties.description: The smell of wood shavings suffuses the air within the red brick walls of the Martin & Co factory. Artisans chisel, bend, shape, polish and glue together guitars alongside the 1833 shop, named after the year that the company was founded. Now and then a drill sounds, mingling with the odd twang of a string, and a flurry of sawdust flutters like snow to the workshop floor. Now and then, families come round on tours arranged by the company. Neil doesn’t like it when loud children come along, destroying his concentration as he hones the fretboard or sets the bridge in place. Today, no tours, but a single hair falls into the body of the guitar while the glue inside is still wet. It lies there, undetected, as the finished instrument is packaged up for distribution to California.
properties.title: Guitar Manufacture

properties.description: Emilio had worked at the Guitar Centre for a few days. Today he’d been late, for the first time, because his alarm clock hadn’t gone off. He’d been out playing bass for the band the night before, and they’d all gone drinking afterwards. Things got a little out of hand and everyone had ended up back at D’arcy’s house smoking weed and putting the world to rights. It was a crisp and beautiful morning, but Emilio wasn’t feeling it. The bitterness of his coffee blessedly overwhelmed the lingering taste of last night’s tequila as he sat hunched over his mug. A man walked in. Skinny with shoulder-length hair, tatty Bon Jovi t-shirt, Converse sneakers. Standard. The guy sized up the guitars hanging lovingly in rows around the store. Emilio didn’t offer to help. Finally, the customer picked down a Martin. Emilio couldn’t even bring himself to mutter “nice choice” as he rang it through, beset as he was by a pounding headache. At least the guy hadn’t played Stairway to Heaven. Small blessings.
properties.address: 1645 Van Ness Avenue, San Francisco, CA 94109, USA
properties.placename: 1645 Van Ness Avenue, San Francisco, CA 94109, USA
properties.title: Guitar Centre

properties.description: A quiet Christmas. It had just been the two of them, years before the kids were born. Sarah awoke to Martin bringing coffee and pastries into the bedroom. She remembers fondly how he lent over to kiss her and nearly knocked a full latte onto the carpet. Not that it would have mattered, a coffee stain would have only improved the interior decoration.  When they went into the living room, there it was under their makeshift Christmas branch, festooned with paperchains made from the pages of catalogues. A Martin guitar, from her Martin. She played it every day since, except when she was in hospital in labour.  The guitar's soft mahogany body vibrates with every pluck of its steel strings. It sings to Sarah's touch just as her own body sings to Martin's fingers running over her skin.
properties.title: Sarah's Guitar
Red Cedar Wood to Guitar Manufacture

properties.description: What networks flow into and out of your life? A woman sits at her kitchen diner in Chula Vista, San Diego. She looks around, noting the first things upon which her eyes fall. Where did they come from? What stories do they tell? How do they connect her to strangers across the globe? Click on each point and read the story.
properties.title: Flow #1
